lexUnit.name: reprimand.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a formal expression of disapproval.

sentence.text: But if the Section Sergeant goes in for any necessary purpose , the Inspector comes in , he is reported and gets a severe reprimand from his superiors for idling his time in the Station .
He gave Captain Lake a severe reprimand for his brutality and ordered him to return to Sombrero to see if Jeffrey were alive and , if so , to rescue him .
Batley and Sheffield Eagles received a severe reprimand yesterday for the fighting which took place during their first-round Yorkshire Cup tie .
He got a good-natured reprimand from Mona for not setting a good example to the lower classes .
Despite an immediate reprimand from Chamorro , Godoy 's statements during the strike reportedly encouraged the formation of right-wing armed groups .
I even got a reprimand from my creep of a Minister .
Others suffer reprimands while the Cowes Organising Committee themselves face a structure review .
The House also has the power to admonish or issue a reprimand to those in contempt .
Later there came a reprimand for a breach of rules and , not long after , a six month suspension for a further misdemeanour .
Jefferies ' excuse was accepted and , after a reprimand from John Martin for not behaving like a man , he was asked to sit down .
Just as we were about to leave , Frank Dick called me to one side and gave me a blistering reprimand .
The statement was a veiled reprimand .
There 's a reprimand on his record for improper treatment of a prisoner of war . "
